MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

License #: CB810406448

Agency Name: Our House- Mosaic

YPSILANTI, MI 48197-4644

License Expiration Date: 01/25/2024

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
Section (1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
Description independent living as the most appropriate placement for the
youth.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that a youth was placed inappropriately into
independent living.
Investigation The agency Chief Administrator was interviewed via
telephone on August 18, 2023. Chief Administrator reported the
agency receives referrals from DHHS for the Independent Living
Program (ILP). Chief Administrator reported Youth A was
interviewed twice by the agency prior to placement and stated
“Youth A interviewed great”. Youth A was a 17-year-old female at
the time of placement and turned eighteen in September 2023.
Chief Administrator reported the case referral packet was
reviewed and discussion was conducted with the referral source
prior to placement. Chief Administrator reported the agency
expected Youth A to experience adjustment issues initially but felt
she was appropriate for the program. Chief Administrator reported
the program is staffed 16 hours per day and Youth A would be
obtaining support services from Community Mental Health as well
as life skills and support from agency staff.
DHHS Services Supervisor was interviewed via phone on
September 29, 2023. DHHS Services Supervisor is the referral
source for Youth A. DHHS Services Supervisor reported Youth A
does have some emotional issues however the agency felt that
her problems were not of a nature to prevent placement in the ILP.
DHHS Services Supervisor also reported there were no relative
placements available as the biological mother of Youth A
sabotages any relative placement opportunity. DHHS Service
Supervisor reported due to the age of Youth A foster care
placements were not available. DHHS Services Supervisor
reported Youth A is currently doing well in the ILP.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on October 2nd, and
3rd, 2023. Staff 1 is an agency case worker. Staff 1 reported
Youth A is doing much better from a difficult start in the program.
Youth A attends online schooling with the option to attend school
in person. Staff 1 reported Youth A frequently attends school in
person and enjoys it. Staff 1 reported Youth A has not been
assaultive since initially engaging in this behavior in August 2023.
Staff 1 reported Youth A has her own set of friends outside of the
program and does not associate with other youth in the program.
Staff 1 reported Youth A is utilizing life skills by seeking
employment and has had jobs but will quit and seek different
employment. Staff 1 reported Youth A uses public transportation
and does not rely on agency staff for transportation. Staff 1
2

submitted documents for review and reported the agency is
revising their referral packet.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
Referral information received from DHHS Monitor: The packet,
dated March 24, 2023, was reviewed. The packet was completed
and signed by DHHS Monitor and signed by Youth A. The packet
describes in part, that Youth A will soon be turning 18 years of age
and needs a supportive living environment. The packet further
describes that Youth A is knowledgeable about how to take care
of herself and needs positive support in her life. The referral
packet does not describe any issues or concerns that would
prevent placement in the program.
Agency Referral Packet: The agency referral packet was
reviewed. The packet states in part, “Youth may have a
demonstrated history of unsuccessful foster care placements. This
program is also designed as a post-placement resource for youth in
which all of the following apply:
• Youth leaving residential foster care who cannot return home.
• Youth who cannot be placed into a family foster home.
• Youth for whom adoption is not planned”
The packet further describes eligibility requirements and mental
health problems that a youth may have does not prohibit his/her
admission to the program.
Case Service plan: Three case service plans dated August 14,
2023, May 16, 2023, and February 15, 2023, were reviewed. The
plans document Youth A has had suicidal ideations, seizures, and
mental health diagnoses. The August 14, 2023, USP describes
Youth A breaking house rules, and having suicidal ideations.
Psychological Evaluation: A psychological evaluation of Youth
A, dated January 27, 2020, and conducted by Pine Rest, identifies
PTSD, Generalized anxiety disorder, and major depressive
disorder.
FTM Documentation: An FTM was held on August 2, 2023,
indicating the agency had put in a 30-day notice for removal due
to Youth A’s behaviors, (drug use and verbal/physical assault)
however the agency rescinded the notice as Youth A recommitted
to the program.
Analysis The agency Chief Administrator, DHHS Services Supervisor, and
Staff 1 reported Youth A was appropriate for the program and is
3

currently doing well despite an initial difficult beginning.
Information obtained by the agency from the referral packet and
completed by DHHS Monitor does not prevent placement in the
program. The information is congruent with the agency’s eligibility
requirements.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
The recommendation is for continuance of the regular license.
October 3, 2023
______________________________________
Douglas W Turrill Date
